Message.Title: Intel Wants Windows Phone Engineers
Message.Msg: [Let's hope that shorts can hang in until the Mobile World Congress later this month and really get their heads handed to them in a basket. Lots of exciting announcements and news coming out. Intel's mobility traction is ramping up...] [Motorola X phone, slew of smartphones, tablets and Ultrabooks, the Windows Phone...] "Yup, Intel is set to make a splash at Mobile World Congress later this month with a slew of smartphones, tablets and Ultrabooks, and we have also seen how LinkedIn was used to help recruit folks to help out with the upcoming Motorola X phone. Well, LinkedIn is in the spotlight again now, as we have word that Intel has published a job opportunity on LinkedIn which is looking out for Windows Phone engineers. One can read into that however one wants to, but how about this – could Intel be looking into a mobile platform as part of their future investment? The job listed at LinkedIn specifically requested for those who are experts in the Windows Phone environment, and it would be interesting to see what else the future will bring. At this point in time, Windows Phone devices are powered mostly by ARM with Qualcomm as the exclusive chip provider, but two is definitely company from our perspective, and neither do I think that three’s a crowd. The job description’s opening pitch reads as such, “Windows Phone Engineers: Intel would like to talk to you. If you have Windows phone expertise, the Intel site in Redmond would like to talk to you.”"

Message.Title: Time to buy again!
Message.Msg: Intel will explode to the upside starting in second quarter. - Haswell will spur PC pent-up refresh cycle as corporation adopt Windows 8 - Gross margins will get back above 60% as there will be no more excess capacity charges (factories utilization will be back to normal) nor impact of higher factory startup costs. - More design wins for smartphones with CloverTraill+. Don't be surprise to see phones with CloverTrail+ with LTE 4G support hitting US markets this year! - PCs hybrids will continue to blur the lines between tablets and PCs and more and more people will opt for a PC hybrid as 'best of both world' value proposition takes hold. - Possible huge foundries deals with Cisco and/or Apple.

Message.Title: CloverTrail+ with qualcomm baseband = Intel smartphone for US market
Message.Msg: Why can't phone makers use Intel CPU/GPU with qualcomm's 4G LTE? Also on the 4th quarter conference call, P.O stated: "In 2013, we'll also begin to deliver the industry's first 22-nanometer tablet and smartphone SoCs to OEMs. We are now shipping our single-mode data LTE baseband to customers and over the course of the year, we'll begin delivering multimode data and voice modems to customers, giving us a full complement of competitive technologies to grow our device business." So don't count out an Intel-based smartphone with 4G LTE support for US market this year!

Message.Title: Haswell intro will be true Windows 8 launch
Message.Msg: Expect thinner, lighter and longer lasting battery life with Haswell products. Imagine a thinner, lighter version of the following products: Lenovo Yoga Lenovo Helix Asus Asus Transformer Book TX300 All with over 10 hours of battery life!

Message.Title: Asus Fonepad - 7" Android Tablet running on Intel Lexington - $265
Message.Msg: Seems like we can look forward to a crop of Android Tablets based on Intel SoCs at MWC... =================== ASUS FonePad 7-inch Tablet Leaked, Packs Intel CPU and Android Jelly Bean ASUS is one the first company in the world that developed a tablet member of the Nexus tribe. As you probably guessed, I am talking about the popular Nexus 7 unveiled last year in June, synchronized with the debut of Android 4.1 Jelly Bean. The Nexus 7 became such a huge success mostly because of its technical specs and price point, using the same recipe that helped Amazon Kindle fire climb to the top of the best-selling Android tablets in Q4 2011. It seems that ASUS has learned its lesson from the the collaboration with Google, and after the rumor mill hinted that the Taiwan-based company will bring two new affordable tablets at MWC 2013, MeMo Pad 7 and MeMo Pad 10, today we’ve found out about a new cheap ASUS tablet. Apparently, ASUS is readying a new 7-inch tablet, named Fonepad. Yes, the name is a bit confusing, especially that the Taiwanese company already has the Padfone and Padfone 2 smartphone-tablet combo in its portfolio. But let’s forget the name and have a look inside the alleged ASUS Fonepad. Surprisingly enough, it looks like it will be underpinned by an Intel Atom CPU, as leaked Postel Indonesia’s database suggests. The reports are also indicating that the affordable ASUS Fonepad will boast a 7-inch display with IPS technology and a resolution of 1,2800 x 800, and if the price is right it might be a rival worthy of Google’s… errr, ASUS’ Nexus 7. The technical specs sheet also includes 1 GB of RAM, 16 GB of internal storage, 3 megapixel camera on the back of the case, Android 4.1 Jelly Bean out of the box and all the connectivity features worthy of a modern tablet: 3G, WiFi, Bluetooth, and GPS. The price of the ASUS Fonepad also leaked, and it seems that the 7-inch tablet will cost as much as $265. Will it be worth it? We can’t know yet, especially because we have very little info about the Atom Z2420 Lexington chipset. So far, Intel has only provided its processors for terminals meant for the emergent markets, and, to be honest, most of them came with sub-par performance. After the Kindle Fire and Nexus 7 changed people’s perspective on the affordable 7-inch tablets, as both provided decent performance, thus the Intel Lexington platform underpinning the ASUS Fonepad must meet their expectations. Well, at least it will come with above-par battery life, as Intel has always cared about this aspect of their chips. The reports are also claiming that the ASUS Fonepad will also have calling facilities, making the tablet even more interesting. Do you think the Taiwan-based company will bring the ASUS Fonepad at Mobile World Congress 2013 event that debuts later next month? androidDOTgs/asus-fonepad/

Message.Title: Euro Zone Economy Showing Signs of Recovery, Optimism Builds
Message.Msg: The euro zone's embattled economy has turned a corner, according to a business survey on Tuesday that showed businesses are more optimistic about the future but highlighted a growing chasm between the region's economies. Markit's Eurozone Composite PMI, which gauges business activity across thousands of companies and is seen as good gauge of growth, rose in January to a 10-month high of 48.6 from 47.2 in December - an improvement on the preliminary reading of 48.2. While still signalling a contraction as the index has been below the 50 mark that signifies growth since February last year, it has risen consistently in the last three readings. Private industry makes up nearly two-thirds of the euro zone's economy and worryingly for policymakers, the data showed a widening chasm between Germany - Europe's largest economy - and France, the bloc's second biggest. "The euro zone is showing clear signs of healing, with the downturn easing sharply in January and the region moving closer to stabilization in the first quarter," said Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit.

Topic.Title: INTC holding up in market retreat

Message.Msg: Your question makes perfect sense. Your confusion makes perfect sense too. Welcome to the club. 8-) Disclosure: I have no special knowledge other than what I have read in public documents (SEC, ....) and have pieced together over several years of observations. The OMM prices the dividend into the option price. As the ex-dividend day gets near, the dividend premium gets 100% reflected into the PUT and 0% reflected into the Call. That is why Intel call options are so cheap when compared to the puts. The day of ex-dividend, the dividend effect springs back to normal with near 50%/50% match of put/call premium. Arbitraging is "trying to take advantage of this pricing discontinuity". The OMM is a special trader who combined the short + selling the option to make a profit. He made sure that he could short the stock at a high enough price to guarantee a small profit before he did it. Someone entered a trade that required the OMM to supply 5000 puts. He filled the order when he could short INTC at a price that made the equation work: STRIKE PRICE + DIVIDEND + costs + PENNY PROFIT = SHORT + PUT PREMIUM The spread on the options allows for him to do this. One reason that shares trade near strike prices is that OPTION PREMIUMS are highest at the strike prices because the leverage is highest. NOTE: many times that the option trades are complex and involve many legs. If you read on synthetic option strategy .... and understand the SYNTHETIC LONG and SYNTHETIC SHORT you will be on your way. synthetic option arbitrage
This is turning out to be a great pick, these guys alerted it first.

Topic.Title: INTC holding up in market retreat

Message.Msg: The open interest left over from yesterdays trades that I described. The 5,000 $25 MAY puts & calls are still open. The puts may be an exit following the ex-dividend or part of a different trade. It is rarely possible to tell whether an option trade was triggered by the OMM or someone else. It is also tough to know who was on which side and what their motive was. 8.8k Jan 2015 $15 strike OPEN INTEREST 8.4k 1.6k Jan 2015 $13 strike OPEN INTEREST 328 38k Jan 2014 $15 OPEN INTEREST 2.7k looks like 35000 call contracts involved 2k Jan 2014 $13 OPEN INTEREST 118 3k Jan 2014 $10 OPEN INTEREST 113 26k Feb $20 OPEN INTEREST 2.9k looks like 20000 call contracts involved around 50,000 call contracts missing and reflects about 5,000,000 INTC shares.

Message.Title: Writing on the wall for ARMH
Message.Msg: I didn't go to CES this year but one of my friends went and said there wasn't a lot to get excited about. No real big introductions. I mentioned that ARM based products really haven't improved dramatically since last year. He said that what he saw was newer versions of the same old same old. So, don't take my word for it, go over to the ARMH website and read the blog about CES. Someone named Jim Wallace wrote about ARMH at CES. In the article he mentioned ARM 9 times. Here's the first paragraph "CES was a great show for ARM, there were plenty of ARM powered smartphones, families of Mali™ GPU enabled Android tablets, from entry level brands to the latest Google Nexus 10 with 2.5K displays, and larger than ever Mali GPU enabled 4K smartTVs." Smart TV's and 4K TVs? The Smart TV was on display last year at CES. They were neat to play with for a few minutes, but it wasn't anything that made me want to go out and buy one. The 4K displays were also demo'd last year. The panel makers are in a bit of a loss. They felt certain that consumers wanted 3D TV. Nope. In order to enjoy 4K you need two things. a TV large enough to really show all 4000 pixels and a hell of a lot more data coming in to populate all those pixels. Consumers demanding 4K tvs in the next year or two isn't a pipe dream, it's a crack pipe dream. We're talking about consumers, the people who are happy streaming movies in 720p. So what was missing from CES for ARMH? The dangling carrot. Every year there has been something that ARM has presented that made consumers say "Wow, I need that." If it didn't happen at CES we'd know that Apple would have it a few weeks later at a press conference. Neither happened this year. ARMH has stated again and again that it has a two year lead with Intel. It could use this lead to distance itself from Intel. I am not saying that ARMH isn't a strong company or it doesn't have a viable future. All I am asking is what is it doing with this lead? Where is the next big thing for ARMH? I see plans of down the road things like data centers and 4K TVs. What is the hot ARMH product consumers are dreaming about that they can get this year? A Nexus 10 tablet? Anything else?

Topic.Title: Writing on the wall for ARMH

Message.Msg: Just how exactly does ARM have a 2 year lead on Intel in anything?

"Hey 61 - tell that to NVDA - " NVDA is down for their R&D is a year behind their roadmap... "Me think East is getting decoupled from reality " Reality is ARMH is at new highs... !!!!! "there's no reason why Intel should have a long-term sustainable lead." Yes, even with superior fabs... ya won't need x86... The world is going ARM...

'ARM will be everywhere ... !!!!' ... except in successful profitable Nvidia chips ;-). This is not an all time high, they did $48.60 in y2k. Their eps just made expectations which shows margins are getting squeezed contrary to their BS story. We are near the top of this bubble and ARMH will be $10-15 within 5 years around the same time when INTC will be $40-50. A15 is going to be a commercial failure, it's too hot to run at full clockspeeds in phones, it will be outperformed in performance/power by Atom and performance by Core processors. Never mind any future fabrication dead-ends they have already reached a design dead-end with A15. Nvidia has to create a portable console to sell theirs because no-one is interested in putting it in a tablet or phone ;-).
Thank You... just have to settle for another 52-week high... as previously claimed... ARMH is a rubber stamp... Time will show what the world can do with their ISA... starts 2014

NVDA is down for a lot more reasons than just being one year behind on an already poor roadmap. They are 2 years behind in reality if you go back far enough in time to see their Project Denver projections for 2012 ! Tegra is not a successful commercial product and does not look likely to be in the near future. It was supposed to replace the motherboard business profits and has failed in that regard. Low to medium end discrete gpus are being squeezed out of the market by each new generation of Intel and AMD on-die gpus and that's just going to continue with Haswell. Nvidia is a company treading water on legacy business, you should have put your money in ARMH instead if you like their business model so much because NVDA is not going anywhere fast for the foreseeable future.

Topic.Title: I thought INTC closed at 21.15 yesterday?

Message.Msg: On EX-DIV date (which is today 02/05/2013 for INTC) the price of the stock is reduced by the amount of the dividend (in this case 22.5 cents). The company pays the share holders the dividend, unless you are short, in which case you pay the dividend. Google "what is ex-dividend date" and it will hopefully make more sense. Basically, the company is worth that much less after paying the dividend, so the stock price is adjusted to reflect that.

Topic.Title: Asus Fonepad - 7" Android Tablet running on Intel Lexington - $265

Message.Msg: gsmarenaDOTcom/xolo-x500-gets-benchmarked-sports-intel-atom-z2420-cpu/ Xolo X500 and its Intel Atom Z2420 CPU get benchmarked, get pretty good scores January 31st, 2013, 20:20 bySunil26 comments Xolo X500, which was launched a week ago in India, has just been benchmarked. The smartphone is designed for emerging markets with low cost at higher priority than stellar performance, but it did surprisingly well. Perhaps a part of the explanation is that the Intel chip also uses its hyper threading technology, which has better multi-tasking ability. The smartphone is powered by a 1.2 GHz Intel Atom Lexington Z2420 processor along with Power VR SGX540 GPU. The Atom-powered Xolo X500 is right behind the Xolo X900, which is powered by the Medfield chipset in the Quadrant benchmark tests. However the X500 managed to beat its more expensive sibling at the AnTuTu benchmark. The smartphone aggregates 12859 points in the AnTuTu 3.0 benchmark, which is not bad at all. Xolo X500 is on top of Vellamo 1.0 browser benchmark tests too and scores a hefty 1168 and 421 points in the HTML5 web browser tests and CPU subsystem performance respectively The X500 also managed to max out the NenaMark 2 benchmark. At the onscreen GLBenchmark test it only managed 18fps, but it should still do pretty well with all but the heaviest games.

Topic.Title: Writing on the wall for ARMH

Message.Msg: Clearly both Intel and ARM have opportunities to go after each other's markets but all things considered Intel is far better positioned to capture ARM's business than vice versa. - Lenovo K900 released to very good reviews and the benchmarks shows Intel's dual-core SoC's rivaling Samsung's quad-core in Galaxy phones. - The x86-based Surface Pro arrives to retail this week. This introduces a totally new class of tablets for enterprise and those needing to do more than play games. - New Ultrabooks and convertibles are arriving on the market that can displace some iPad and Android tablet sales. - New low x86 Android tablets arriving on the market (see the Asus product) that will compete head-to-head against Android tablets with ARM. - And Intel's product release schedule this year and next is absolutely phenomenal. But where is ARM's competition to Intel's server business? It's hardly more than a dream.
Insiders sell every January in this company-- market may be overextended some but INTC is too good a company with way too much R and D $$$ and talented brainiacs to not be successful long term.

Message.Title: Upstream supply chain sees good profit from Intel Classmate PC shipments
Message.Msg: Despite fierce competitions within the notebook and the tablet markets, netbook and tablet products are currently still seeing good demand in the education segment, especially Intel's Classmate PC and Studybook products, which have a higher gross margin than standard PC products and can assist their upstream suppliers to achieve profit, according to sources from the upstream supply chain. Intel has already shipped more than 10 million Classmate PCs since the launch of the device and is expected to ship 3-4 million StudyBook tablets in 2013. Intel's Classmate PC orders are mostly from emerging markets such as China, Turkey, Thailand and India as well as countries in Eastern Europe and Latin America. From Monica Chen
":) I think you are going to be surprised at the performance/power/price profile of the A15 family over the next few months..." [Well, that or the lack of...]

Topic.Title: ARM Breaking New Highs and Getting Ready to Break

Message.Msg: The rapidly growing mobile market can easily mask the impact Intel's assault will have on ARM for a while (possibly even a year ) because Intel's presence will not show up as fewer total sales to ARM but rather as a slower rate of growth for ARM which is more difficult to identify as many market expansion can be influenced by many things. However, once the slower growth-rate has been spotted in ARM's business, along with concurrent rise in Intel's, the inflection point will have occurred and the bubble will have ended. One undeniable fact is that ARM cannot remain unaffected by Intel's focused pursuit of the mobile business.

Message.Title: MWC 2013: Intel Takes Offensive in Battle for Mobile Supremacy
Message.Msg: MWC 2013: Intel Takes Offensive in Battle for Mobile Supremacy Two new SoCs: Atom Z2580 and Atom Z2420 Mobile Devices News Published: February 5, 2013 4:18 PM By Régis Jehl Translated by: Hugh Ehreth Send to a friend Three weeks from now, at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Intel will be presenting two new SoCs for mobile devices. Should Nvidia, Qualcomm and Samsung be worried? At CES 2013 in Las Vegas, Intel's biggest talking point was its upcoming mobile SoC, Bay Trail. This new addition to the Atom range will have a new architecture with a finer transistor process. But it won't be released until late 2013/early 2014.

Topic.Title: MWC 2013: Intel Takes Offensive in Battle for Mobile Supremacy

Message.Msg: Until then, the Santa Clara firm isn't just sitting on its laurels; it has just announced that it will be launching the Atom Z2580 and Z2420. The Z2580 is a high-end system-on-chip that will be featured in the Lenovo K900 smartphone. It has a 1.3 GHz dual-core processor with a turbo mode that boosts the clock rate up to 1.8 GHz and supports Hyper-Threading. As a result the SoC will behave as though it had four cores, two physical and two logic

Topic.Title: I don't know why people keep comparing ARM vs Intel. ARM is nowhere in the picture

Message.Msg: zdnetDOTcom/nvidia-high-performance-arm-servers-one-or-two-years-away-7000006513/ Nvidia: High performance ARM servers 'one or two years' away Summary: Nvidia believes that high-performance servers will remain the domain of the x86 architecture for the next few years, but that ARM processors, combined with the power of the GPU, will eventually take over. By Adrian Kingsley-Hughes for Hardware 2.0 | October 29, 2012 -- 09:43 GMT (02:43 PDT) While there's a certain allure to using ARM processors for server applications because of their low power consumption, Nvidia believes the chips won't be ready for high performance applications for a couple of years. Sumit Gupta, general manager of Nvidia's Tesla accelerated computing unit, sees the x86 architecture as being the king of the server room, for the time being at any rate. "Performance of these ARM cores is still not where it needs to be for servers. It is getting there; the new ARM64 is going to get it part of the way," said Gupta, as reported by The Inquirer. "One day I think ARM will at least get to similar performance levels as X86 performance. The belief is that over the next one or two years these ARM SoCs will be good enough for cloud applications and web serving. I think it will take some more time to be good enough for accelerated computing".

Topic.Title: I don't know why people keep comparing ARM vs Intel. ARM is nowhere in the picture

Message.Msg: ARM64 is going to get it PART of the way? in 1-2 years? Intel's Atom 64bit is already there and selling for $50. And ATOM64 will only get a lot better with Baytrail and 22nm. ARM64 will ALWAYS be INFERIOR to Atom64, and with NO software compatibility, its as good as DOA.

A SoC might be a different "beast" compared to CPU but there should be no difference in how SoC or CPU wafers are processed (similar process flow) - IOW by the time the Intel 22nm SoC hits the process should be more or less fully debugged. Intel processed millions of trigate wafers - and that's how yields are being improved and fine tuned and that should be real advantage for Intel SoC cost structure. SoC and CPU are different when it comes to test equipment at least to my knowledge
